# Jennifer Lawrence

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Jennifer Lawrence  
---  
[![A photograph of actress Jennifer Lawrence at the 2015 San Diego Comic-Con
International](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Jennifer_Lawrence_SDCC_2015_X-
Men.jpg/220px-Jennifer_Lawrence_SDCC_2015_X-

actress Jennifer Lawrence at the 2015 San Diego Comic-Con International")
Lawrence at the 2015 [San Diego Comic-Con
International](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con
International") promoting _[X-Men: Apocalypse](/wiki/X-Men:_Apocalypse "X-Men:
Apocalypse")_  
Born | Jennifer Shrader Lawrence  
(1990-08-15) August 15, 1990 (age 27)  
[Indian Hills, Kentucky](/wiki/Indian_Hills,_Kentucky "Indian Hills,
Kentucky"), U.S.  
Occupation | Actress

Awards | [Full list](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Jennifer_Lawrence "List of awards and nominations received by Jennifer Lawrence")  
  
**Jennifer Shrader Lawrence** (born August 15, 1990) is an American actress.
Her films have grossed over $5.5 billion worldwide, and she was the highest-
paid actress in the world in 2015 and 2016. She appeared in
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ 's [100 most influential
people in the world](/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100") in 2013 and in the [_Forbes_
Celebrity 100](/wiki/Forbes_Celebrity_100 "Forbes Celebrity 100") in 2014 and
2016.

During her childhood, Lawrence performed in church plays and school musicals.
When she was 14, a talent scout spotted her in New York City. She then moved
to Los Angeles and began her acting career by playing guest roles in
television shows. Her first major role came as a main cast member on the
sitcom _[The Bill Engvall Show](/wiki/The_Bill_Engvall_Show "The Bill Engvall
Show")_ (2007–2009). Lawrence made her film debut in a supporting role in
_[Garden Party](/wiki/Garden_Party_\(film\) "Garden Party \(film\)")_ (2008),
and had her breakthrough playing a poverty-stricken teenager in the
independent drama _[Winter's Bone](/wiki/Winter%27s_Bone "Winter's Bone")_
(2010). She achieved wider recognition for starring as the mutant
[Mystique](/wiki/Mystique_\(comics\) "Mystique \(comics\)") in _[X-Men: First
Class](/wiki/X-Men:_First_Class "X-Men: First Class")_ (2011), a role she
reprised in later installments of the [series](/wiki/X-Men_\(film_series\)
"X-Men \(film series\)").

Lawrence's fame continued to grow with her starring role as [Katniss
Everdeen](/wiki/Katniss_Everdeen "Katniss Everdeen") in the [_Hunger Games_
film series](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games_\(film_series\) "The Hunger Games \(film
series\)") (2012–2015), which established her as the highest-grossing [action
heroine](/wiki/List_of_female_action_heroes "List of female action heroes") of
all time. She went on to earn [various
accolades](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Jennifer_Lawrence
"List of awards and nominations received by Jennifer Lawrence") for her
collaborations with director [David O. Russell](/wiki/David_O._Russell "David
O. Russell"). Her performance as a depressed and bipolar widow in the romance
film _[Silver Linings Playbook](/wiki/Silver_Linings_Playbook "Silver Linings
Playbook")_ (2012) earned her an [Academy Award for Best
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Actress"), making her the [second-youngest winner of the
award](/wiki/List_of_oldest_and_youngest_Academy_Award_winners_and_nominees#Best_Actress_in_a_Leading_Role
"List of oldest and youngest Academy Award winners and nominees"). Lawrence
subsequently won a [BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting
Role](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actress_in_a_Supporting_Role "BAFTA Award for
Best Actress in a Supporting Role") for playing a troubled wife in the black
comedy _[American Hustle](/wiki/American_Hustle "American Hustle")_ (2013).
She also received [Golden Globe Awards](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe
Award") for her roles in both of these films and for her performance as [Joy
Mangano](/wiki/Joy_Mangano "Joy Mangano") in the biopic
_[Joy](/wiki/Joy_\(film\) "Joy \(film\)")_ (2015).

Lawrence is known in the media as an advocate for [feminism](/wiki/Feminism
"Feminism") and gender equality. She is the founder of the Jennifer Lawrence
Foundation, through which she supports various charitable organizations.

## Early life

Jennifer Shrader Lawrence was born on August 15, 1990 in [Indian Hills,
Kentucky](/wiki/Indian_Hills,_Kentucky "Indian Hills, Kentucky"), to Gary, a
construction worker, and Karen ([née](/wiki/Given_name#Name_at_birth "Given
name") Koch), a [summer camp](/wiki/Summer_camp "Summer camp") manager.[1][2]
She has two older brothers, Ben and Blaine,[2] and her mother brought her up
to be "tough" like them. Karen did not allow her daughter to play with other
girls in preschool as she deemed her "too rough" with them.[3] The future
actress was educated at the [Kammerer Middle
School](/wiki/Public_schools_in_Louisville,_Kentucky "Public schools in
Louisville, Kentucky") in [Louisville](/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky "Louisville,
Kentucky").[3] She did not enjoy her childhood due to hyperactivity and social
anxiety and considered herself a misfit among her peers.[2][4] Lawrence has
said that her anxieties vanished when she performed on stage and acting gave
her a sense of accomplishment.[4]

Lawrence's school activities included cheerleading, softball, field hockey and
basketball, which she played on a boys' team that was coached by her
father.[3] While growing up, she was fond of horseback riding and frequently
visited a local horse farm.[5] She has an injured [tailbone](/wiki/Coccyx
"Coccyx") as a result of being thrown from a horse.[6] Lawrence said that she
knew from an early age that she would be famous.[2] When her father worked
from home, she performed for him, often dressing up as a clown or
ballerina.[7] She had her first acting assignment at age nine when she played
the role of a prostitute in a church play that was based on the [Book of
Jonah](/wiki/Book_of_Jonah "Book of Jonah"). For the next few years, she
continued to take parts in church plays and school musicals.[3]

Lawrence was 14 and on a family vacation to New York City when she was spotted
on the street by a talent scout who arranged for her to audition for talent
agents.[8][9] Karen was not keen on allowing her daughter to pursue an acting
career, but she briefly moved her family to the city to let her read for
roles.[3] After Lawrence's first [cold
reading](/wiki/Cold_reading_\(theatrical\) "Cold reading \(theatrical\)"), the
agents said that hers was the best they had heard from someone that young;
Lawrence's mother convinced her that they were lying.[9] Lawrence said her
early experiences were difficult because she felt lonely and friendless.[3]
She signed on with the CESD Talent Agency, who convinced her parents to let
her audition for roles in Los Angeles. Lawrence's mother agreed to let her
pursue acting on the condition that she graduate from high school. Lawrence
was eventually home-schooled in Los Angeles and graduated two years early with
good grades.[9][10] At that time, she considered acting to be a natural fit
for her talents, and she turned down several offers for modelling
assignments.[8] Between her acting jobs in the city, she made regular visits
to Louisville, where she served as an assistant nurse at her mother's
camp.[11]

## Career

### 2006–2010: Career beginnings and breakthrough

Lawrence began her acting career with a minor role in the television film
_Company Town_ (2006). She followed it with guest roles in several television
shows, including _[Monk](/wiki/Monk_\(TV_series\) "Monk \(TV series\)")_
(2006) and _[Medium](/wiki/Medium_\(TV_series\) "Medium \(TV series\)")_
(2007).[12] These parts led to her being cast as a series regular on the
[TBS](/wiki/TBS_\(TV_network\) "TBS \(TV network\)") sitcom _[The Bill Engvall
Show](/wiki/The_Bill_Engvall_Show "The Bill Engvall Show")_ , in which she
played [Lauren](/wiki/The_Bill_Engvall_Show#Characters "The Bill Engvall
Show"), the rebellious teenage daughter of a family living in suburban
[Louisville, Colorado](/wiki/Louisville,_Colorado "Louisville, Colorado").[12]
The series premiered in 2007 and ran for three seasons.[13] [Tom
Shales](/wiki/Tom_Shales "Tom Shales") of _[The Washington
Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ considered her a
[scene stealer](/wiki/Scene_stealer "Scene stealer") in her part, and David
Hinckley of the _[New York Daily News](/wiki/New_York_Daily_News "New York
Daily News")_ wrote that she was successful in "deliver[ing] the perpetual
exasperation of teenage girls".[14][15] Lawrence won a [Young Artist
Award](/wiki/Young_Artist_Award "Young Artist Award") for Outstanding Young
Performer in a TV Series for the role in 2009.[16]

[![Lawrence looking away from the
camera](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Jennifer_Lawrence_at_the_83rd_Academy_Awards_crop.jpg/170px-
Jennifer_Lawrence_at_the_83rd_Academy_Awards_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_at_the_83rd_Academy_Awards_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_at_the_83rd_Academy_Awards_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

Lawrence at the [83rd Academy Awards](/wiki/83rd_Academy_Awards "83rd Academy
Awards") in 2011, where she received her first [Best
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Actress") nomination for _[Winter's Bone](/wiki/Winter%27s_Bone "Winter's
Bone")_

Lawrence made her film debut in the 2008 drama film _[Garden
Party](/wiki/Garden_Party_\(film\) "Garden Party \(film\)")_ , in which she
played a troubled teenager named Tiff.[17] She then appeared in director
[Guillermo Arriaga](/wiki/Guillermo_Arriaga "Guillermo Arriaga")'s feature
film debut _[The Burning Plain](/wiki/The_Burning_Plain "The Burning Plain")_
(2008), a drama narrated in a [hyperlink format](/wiki/Hyperlink_cinema
"Hyperlink cinema"). She was cast as the teenage daughter of [Kim
Basinger](/wiki/Kim_Basinger "Kim Basinger")'s character who discovers her
mother's extramarital affair—a role she shared with [Charlize
Theron](/wiki/Charlize_Theron "Charlize Theron"); both actresses portrayed the
role at different stages of the character's life. Mark Feeney for _[The Boston
Globe](/wiki/The_Boston_Globe "The Boston Globe")_ thought of Lawrence's
performance as "a thankless task", but Derek Elley from
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ praised her as
the production's prime asset, writing that she "plumbs fresher depths" into
the film.[18][19] Her performance earned her the [Premio Marcello
Mastroianni](/wiki/Premio_Marcello_Mastroianni "Premio Marcello Mastroianni")
award for Best Emerging Actress at the [Venice Film
Festival](/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival "Venice Film Festival").[20] Also that
year, she appeared in the music video for the song "The Mess I Made" by
[Parachute](/wiki/Parachute_\(band\) "Parachute \(band\)").[21] The following
year, she starred in [Lori Petty](/wiki/Lori_Petty "Lori Petty")'s drama _[The
Poker House](/wiki/The_Poker_House "The Poker House")_ as the oldest of three
sisters living with a drug-abusing mother.[22][23] Stephen Farber of _[The
Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_
thought that Lawrence "has a touching poise on camera that conveys the
resilience of children", and her role in _The Poker House_ won an Outstanding
Performance award from the [Los Angeles Film
Festival](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Film_Festival "Los Angeles Film
Festival").[24][25]

Lawrence's [breakthrough role](/wiki/Breakthrough_role "Breakthrough role")
came in the small-scale drama _[Winter's Bone](/wiki/Winter%27s_Bone "Winter's
Bone")_ (2010), based on [Daniel Woodrell](/wiki/Daniel_Woodrell "Daniel
Woodrell")'s novel of the same name. In [Debra Granik](/wiki/Debra_Granik
"Debra Granik")'s independent feature, she portrayed Ree Dolly, a poverty-
stricken teenager in the [Ozark Mountains](/wiki/Ozark_Mountains "Ozark
Mountains") who cares for her mentally ill mother and younger siblings while
searching for her missing father. Lawrence traveled to the Ozarks a week
before filming began to live with the family on whom the story was based, and
in preparation, she learned to fight, skin squirrels, and chop wood.[26][27]
[David Denby](/wiki/David_Denby_\(film_critic\) "David Denby \(film critic\)")
of _[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")_ said the film
"would be unimaginable with anyone less charismatic",[28] and [Peter
Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ wrote that "her performance is
more than acting, it's a gathering storm. Lawrence's eyes are a roadmap to
what's tearing Ree apart."[29] The production won the Grand Jury Prize at the
[Sundance Film Festival](/wiki/Sundance_Film_Festival "Sundance Film
Festival").[30] The actress was awarded the [National Board of Review Award
for Breakthrough
Performance](/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Award_for_Breakthrough_Performance
"National Board of Review Award for Breakthrough Performance"), and with her
first nomination for the [Academy Award for Best
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Actress"), she became the [second youngest
person](/wiki/List_of_oldest_and_youngest_Academy_Award_winners_and_nominees
"List of oldest and youngest Academy Award winners and nominees") to be
nominated in the category.[31]

### 2011–2013: Film series and awards success

In 2011, Lawrence took on a supporting role in _[Like
Crazy](/wiki/Like_Crazy_\(2011_film\) "Like Crazy \(2011 film\)")_ , a
romantic drama about long-distance relationships, starring [Anton
Yelchin](/wiki/Anton_Yelchin "Anton Yelchin") and [Felicity
Jones](/wiki/Felicity_Jones "Felicity Jones").[32] [Kenneth
Turan](/wiki/Kenneth_Turan "Kenneth Turan") of the _[Los Angeles
Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ considered the film to be
an "intensely wrought and immensely satisfying love story" and credited all
three performers for "making their [characters'] yearning palpable".[33] She
then appeared in [Jodie Foster](/wiki/Jodie_Foster "Jodie Foster")'s black
comedy _[The Beaver](/wiki/The_Beaver_\(film\) "The Beaver \(film\)")_
alongside Foster and [Mel Gibson](/wiki/Mel_Gibson "Mel Gibson"). Filmed in
2009, the production was delayed due to controversy concerning Gibson, and
earned less than half of its $21 million budget.[34][35]

After her dramatic role in _Winter 's Bone_, Lawrence looked for something
less serious, and found it with her first high-profile release—[Matthew
Vaughn](/wiki/Matthew_Vaughn "Matthew Vaughn")'s superhero film _[X-Men: First
Class](/wiki/X-Men:_First_Class "X-Men: First Class")_ (2011)—a prequel to the
[_X-Men_ film series](/wiki/X-Men_\(film_series\) "X-Men \(film
series\)").[36] She portrayed the [shapeshifting](/wiki/Shapeshifting
"Shapeshifting") mutant [Mystique](/wiki/Mystique_\(comics\) "Mystique
\(comics\)"), a role played by [Rebecca Romijn](/wiki/Rebecca_Romijn "Rebecca
Romijn") in the earlier films.[37] Vaughn cast Lawrence, as he thought that
she would be able to portray the weakness and strength involved in the
character's transformation.[38] Lawrence lost weight for the part, and for
Mystique's blue form had to undergo an eight-hour
[makeup](/wiki/Prosthetic_makeup "Prosthetic makeup"), as Romijn had done on
the other films.[39] She was intimidated in the role as she admired
Romijn.[40] Writing for _[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_ , Claudia
Puig considered the film to be a "classy re-boot" of the film series, and
believed that her "high-spirited performance" empowered the film.[41] With a
worldwide gross of $350 million, _X-Men: First Class_ became Lawrence's most
widely seen film to that point.[42]

[![Actress Jennifer Lawrence attending the 2012 Toronto International Film
Festival](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Jennifer_Lawrence_TIFF_2%2C_2012.jpg/170px-
Jennifer_Lawrence_TIFF_2%2C_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_TIFF_2,_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_TIFF_2,_2012.jpg "Enlarge")

Lawrence at the [2012 Toronto International Film
Festival](/wiki/2012_Toronto_International_Film_Festival "2012 Toronto
International Film Festival")

In 2012 she played [Katniss Everdeen](/wiki/Katniss_Everdeen "Katniss
Everdeen") in _[The Hunger Games](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games_\(film\) "The Hunger
Games \(film\)")_ , an adaptation of the first book in author [Suzanne
Collins](/wiki/Suzanne_Collins "Suzanne Collins")' [_Hunger Games_
trilogy](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games "The Hunger Games"). Set in a [post-
apocalyptic](/wiki/Apocalyptic_and_post-apocalyptic_fiction "Apocalyptic and
post-apocalyptic fiction") future, the series tells the story of the teenage
heroine Everdeen as she joins rebel forces against a totalitarian government
after winning a brutal televised annual event. Despite being an admirer of the
books, Lawrence was initially hesitant to accept the part, because of the
grand scale of the film. She agreed to the project after her mother convinced
her to take the part.[43] She practiced yoga, archery, rock and tree climbing,
and hand-to-hand combat techniques for the role.[3][44][45] While training for
the part, she injured herself running into a wall.[46] The film received
generally positive reviews, and Lawrence's portrayal of Everdeen was
particularly praised.[47] [Todd McCarthy](/wiki/Todd_McCarthy "Todd McCarthy")
of _The Hollywood Reporter_ called her an "ideal screen actress", adding that
she embodies the Everdeen of the novel, and believed that she anchored the
film "with impressive gravity and presence".[48] [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") agreed that she was "strong and
convincing in the central role".[49] With worldwide revenues of over $690
million,[42] _The Hunger Games_ became a top-grossing film featuring a female
lead,[50] making Lawrence the highest-grossing [action
heroine](/wiki/Action_hero "Action hero") of all time.[51] The success of the
film established her as a star.[52]

Later in 2012, Lawrence played a young depressed widow named Tiffany Maxwell
in [David O. Russell](/wiki/David_O._Russell "David O. Russell")'s romance
movie _[Silver Linings Playbook](/wiki/Silver_Linings_Playbook "Silver Linings
Playbook")_. The film was an adaptation of the [Matthew
Quick](/wiki/Matthew_Quick "Matthew Quick")'s [novel of the same
name](/wiki/The_Silver_Linings_Playbook_\(novel\) "The Silver Linings Playbook
\(novel\)"). It follows her character finding companionship with Pat Solitano
Jr. (played by [Bradley Cooper](/wiki/Bradley_Cooper "Bradley Cooper")), a man
with [bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder "Bipolar disorder").[53][54]
The actress was drawn to her character's complex personality: "She didn't
really fit any basic kind of character profile. Somebody who is very forceful
and bullheaded is normally very insecure, but she isn't".[55] While Russell
initially considered Lawrence to be too young for the part, she convinced him
to hire her via a [Skype](/wiki/Skype "Skype") audition.[43] The actress found
herself challenged by Russell's spontaneity as a director, and described
working on the project as the "best experience of my life".[43] [Richard
Corliss](/wiki/Richard_Corliss "Richard Corliss") of
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ wrote: "Just 21 when the
movie was shot, Lawrence is that rare young actress who plays, who _is_ ,
grown-up. Sullen and sultry, she lends a mature intelligence to any role."[56]
Peter Travers believed that Lawrence "is some kind of miracle. She's rude,
dirty, funny, foulmouthed, sloppy, sexy, vibrant, and vulnerable, sometimes
all in the same scene, even in the same breath."[57] She won the [Golden
Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_in_a_Motion_Picture,_Drama
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture, Drama") and Academy
Award for Best Actress for her performance in the film, becoming—at age 22—the
second youngest Best Actress Oscar winner.[58] Her final release of the year
was alongside [Max Thieriot](/wiki/Max_Thieriot "Max Thieriot") and [Elisabeth
Shue](/wiki/Elisabeth_Shue "Elisabeth Shue") in [Mark
Tonderai](/wiki/Mark_Tonderai "Mark Tonderai")'s critically panned thriller
_[House at the End of the Street](/wiki/House_at_the_End_of_the_Street "House
at the End of the Street")_.[59]

_The Devil You Know_ , a small-scale production that Lawrence had filmed for
in 2005, was her first release of 2013.[60] She then reprised the role of
Everdeen in _[The Hunger Games: Catching
Fire](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games:_Catching_Fire "The Hunger Games: Catching
Fire")_ , the second installment in the [_Hunger Games_ film
series](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games_\(film_series\) "The Hunger Games \(film
series\)").[61] While performing the film's underwater stunts, she suffered
from an ear infection that resulted in a brief loss of hearing.[46] With box
office earnings of $865 million, the film remains her highest-grossing
release.[42] Stephanie Zacharek of _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ believed that Lawrence's
portrayal of Everdeen made her an ideal [role model](/wiki/Role_model "Role
model"), and wrote that "there's no sanctimony or pretense of false modesty in
the way Lawrence plays her".[62] She took on a supporting role in Russell's
ensemble crime drama _[American Hustle](/wiki/American_Hustle "American
Hustle")_ (2013) as Rosalyn Rosenfeld, the neurotic wife of con man Irving
Rosenfeld (portrayed by [Christian Bale](/wiki/Christian_Bale "Christian
Bale")). Inspired by the [Federal Bureau of
Investigation](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of
Investigation")'s [Abscam](/wiki/Abscam "Abscam") sting operation, the film is
set against the backdrop of political corruption in 1970s New Jersey.[63][64]
Lawrence did little research for the part, and based her performance on
knowledge of the era from the films and television shows she had seen.[52]
Geoffrey Macnab of _[The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent "The
Independent")_ praised her as "funny and acerbic", especially for an
improvised scene in which she aggressively kisses her husband's mistress
(played by [Amy Adams](/wiki/Amy_Adams "Amy Adams")) on the lips.[63]
Lawrence's performance won her the [Golden
Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture
"Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture") and [BAFTA
Award](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actress_in_a_Supporting_Role "BAFTA Award
for Best Actress in a Supporting Role") for Best Supporting Actress, in
addition to a third [Academy
Award](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actress") nomination, her first in the supporting category.[65]

### 2014–present: Established actress

Lawrence played Serena Pemberton in [Susanne Bier](/wiki/Susanne_Bier "Susanne
Bier")'s depression-era drama _[Serena](/wiki/Serena_\(2014_film\) "Serena
\(2014 film\)")_ (2014), based on the [novel of the same
name](/wiki/Serena_\(novel\) "Serena \(novel\)") by [Ron Rash](/wiki/Ron_Rash
"Ron Rash"). In the film, she and her husband George (portrayed by Bradley
Cooper) are a married couple who become involved in criminal activities after
realizing that they cannot bear children.[66] The project was filmed in 2012,
and was released in 2014 to poor reviews.[67][68] Lawrence then reprised the
role of Mystique in _[X-Men: Days of Future
Past](/wiki/X-Men:_Days_of_Future_Past "X-Men: Days of Future Past")_ , which
served as a sequel to both _[X-Men: The Last
Stand](/wiki/X-Men:_The_Last_Stand "X-Men: The Last Stand")_ (2006) and _X-
Men: First Class_ (2011). The film received positive reviews and grossed
$748.1 million worldwide, becoming the highest-grossing film in the _X-Men_
series to that point.[69][70] Justin Chang of _Variety_ praised her look in
the film but thought that she had little to do but "glower, snarl and let the
[f/x](/wiki/Visual_effects "Visual effects") artists do their thing".[71]
Lawrence's next two releases were in the final parts of _The Hunger Games_
film series _,[Mockingjay – Part
1](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games:_Mockingjay_%E2%80%93_Part_1 "The Hunger Games:
Mockingjay – Part 1")_ (2014) and _[Part
2](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games:_Mockingjay_%E2%80%93_Part_2 "The Hunger Games:
Mockingjay – Part 2")_ (2015).[72] For the musical score of the former film,
she sang the song "[The Hanging
Tree](/wiki/The_Hanging_Tree_\(The_Hunger_Games_song\) "The Hanging Tree \(The
Hunger Games song\)")",[73] which charted on multiple international [singles
charts](/wiki/Record_chart "Record chart").[74] In a review of the final film
in the series, [Manohla Dargis](/wiki/Manohla_Dargis "Manohla Dargis") of
_[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ drew
similarities between her rise to stardom and Everdeen's journey as a rebel
leader, writing: "Lawrence now inhabits the role as effortlessly as breathing,
partly because, like all great stars, she seems to be playing a version of her
'real' self".[75] Both films earned more than $650 million worldwide.[42]

Lawrence worked with Russell for the third time in the biopic
_[Joy](/wiki/Joy_\(film\) "Joy \(film\)")_ (2015), in which she plays the
[eponymous character](/wiki/Joy_Mangano "Joy Mangano"), a troubled single
mother who becomes a successful businessperson after inventing the Miracle
Mop.[76] During production in Boston, the press reported on a disagreement
between Russell and Lawrence that resulted in a "screaming match". She said
that her friendship with Russell made it easier for them to disagree, because
people fight when they really love each other.[77] The film was not as well
received as their previous collaborations, but her performance was
praised.[78] [Richard Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard Roeper") called it
"a wonderfully layered performance that carries the film through its rough
spots and sometime dubious detours" that was her best since _Winter 's
Bone_.[79] She won a third [Golden Globe
Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy"), and
was nominated for another Academy Award for Best Actress, becoming the
youngest person to accrue four Oscar nominations.[80] Lawrence began 2016 by
providing the narration for _[A Beautiful Planet](/wiki/A_Beautiful_Planet "A
Beautiful Planet")_ , a documentary film that explores Earth from the
[International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International
Space Station").[81] She played Mystique for the third time in _[X-Men:
Apocalypse](/wiki/X-Men:_Apocalypse "X-Men: Apocalypse")_ (2016). The film
received mixed reviews, with a consensus that it was overfilled with action
that detracted from the story's themes and cast's performances.[82] Helen
O'Hara from _[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(film_magazine\) "Empire \(film
magazine\)")_ considered the film to be a letdown from the previous
installments of the series, and criticized the actress for making her
character too grim.[83] Despite this, Lawrence was rewarded with Favorite
Movie Actress at the [43rd People's Choice
Awards](/wiki/43rd_People%27s_Choice_Awards "43rd People's Choice
Awards").[84]

[![A full body shot of Jennifer
Lawrence](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Mother%21_07_%2837062033972%29.jpg/180px-
Mother%21_07_%2837062033972%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mother!_07_\(37062033972\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mother!_07_\(37062033972\).jpg "Enlarge")

Lawrence at an event for _[Mother!](/wiki/Mother! "Mother!")_ at the [2017
Toronto International Film
Festival](/wiki/2017_Toronto_International_Film_Festival "2017 Toronto
International Film Festival")

Lawrence was paid $20 million for playing Aurora Lane in the science fiction
film _[Passengers](/wiki/Passengers_\(2016_film\) "Passengers \(2016 film\)")_
(2016), and she received top-billing over co-star [Chris
Pratt](/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt").[85][86] It features Pratt and her as
two people who wake up 90 years too soon from an [induced
hibernation](/wiki/Suspended_animation "Suspended animation") on a spaceship
bound for a new planet. Lawrence says that she felt nervous performing her
first sex scene and kissing a married man (Pratt) on screen; she drank alcohol
to prepare herself for filming.[87] Critical reaction was negative, with a
consensus that the film had a "fatally flawed story", though the chemistry
between Lawrence and Pratt was praised.[88] Responding to the criticism of the
film, Lawrence said, "I thought the script was beautiful—it was this tainted,
complicated love story. It definitely wasn't a failure".[89] [Darren
Aronofsky](/wiki/Darren_Aronofsky "Darren Aronofsky")'s psychological horror
film _[Mother!](/wiki/Mother! "Mother!")_ was Lawrence's sole release of 2017.
She starred as a young woman married to a much-older man (played by [Javier
Bardem](/wiki/Javier_Bardem "Javier Bardem")), who experiences trauma when her
home is invaded by unexpected guests. Lawrence spent three months rehearsing
the film in a warehouse in Brooklyn, despite her reluctance to rehearsals in
her previous assignments.[90] The intense role proved difficult for her to
film; she was put on supplemental oxygen when she hyperventilated one day, and
she also dislocated a rib.[90] _Mother!_ polarized viewers and prompted mass
walkouts.[91] The film was better received by critics;[92] Walter Addiego of
the _[San Francisco Chronicle](/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle "San Francisco
Chronicle")_ labelled it "assaultive" and a "deliberate test of audience
endurance", and credited Lawrence for "never allow[ing] herself to be reduced
simply to a howling victim".[93]

By 2017, Lawrence's films had grossed over $5.6 billion worldwide.[94] The
following year, she starred as Dominika Egorova, a Russian spy who makes
contact with a mysterious [CIA](/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central
Intelligence Agency") agent (played by [Joel Edgerton](/wiki/Joel_Edgerton
"Joel Edgerton")), in Francis Lawrence's espionage thriller _[Red
Sparrow](/wiki/Red_Sparrow "Red Sparrow")_ , based on Jason Matthews' [novel
of the same name](/wiki/Red_Sparrow_\(book\) "Red Sparrow \(book\)").[95] She
learnt to speak in a Russian accent and undertook [ballet](/wiki/Ballet
"Ballet") training for four months.[96] Lawrence was challenged by the
sexuality in her role, but has said that performing the nude scenes made her
feel empowered.[97] _Red Sparrow_ received mixed reviews from critics.[98]
[IndieWire](/wiki/IndieWire "IndieWire")'s Eric Kohn disliked the film's
denouement but praised the performances of Lawrence and [Charlotte
Rampling](/wiki/Charlotte_Rampling "Charlotte Rampling"), stating that "the
considerable talent on display is [the film's] constant saving grace".[99]
[Alonso Duralde](/wiki/Alonso_Duralde "Alonso Duralde") of
_[TheWrap](/wiki/TheWrap "TheWrap")_ criticized the derivative story and the
lack of chemistry between Lawrence and Edgerton.[100]

#### Upcoming projects

Lawrence has committed to star in her fourth _X-Men_ film, subtitled _[Dark
Phoenix](/wiki/X-Men:_Dark_Phoenix "X-Men: Dark Phoenix")_ , which is
scheduled for release in November 2018.[101] Lawrence and [Amy
Schumer](/wiki/Amy_Schumer "Amy Schumer") have written a screenplay for a film
in which they will star.[102] She will star in [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg")'s film adaptation of
photojournalist [Lynsey Addario](/wiki/Lynsey_Addario "Lynsey Addario")'s
memoir _It 's What I Do: A Photographer's Life of Love and War_,[103] and will
feature as [Elizabeth Holmes](/wiki/Elizabeth_Holmes "Elizabeth Holmes"),
founder of the [Theranos](/wiki/Theranos "Theranos") blood testing company, in
[Adam McKay](/wiki/Adam_McKay "Adam McKay")'s film _Bad Blood_.[104] Lawrence
will also produce a film adaptation of Hannah Kent's novel _[Burial
Rites](/wiki/Burial_Rites "Burial Rites")_ and star as Agnes Magnúsdóttir, the
last woman to be executed for murder in Iceland.[105]

## Personal life

While filming _X-Men: First Class_ in 2010, Lawrence began a romantic
relationship with her co-star [Nicholas Hoult](/wiki/Nicholas_Hoult "Nicholas
Hoult"). The couple broke up around the time they wrapped _X-Men: Days of
Future Past_ in 2014.[106][107] Also that year, she was one of the victims of
the [iCloud leaks of celebrity photos](/wiki/ICloud_leaks_of_celebrity_photos
"ICloud leaks of celebrity photos") when nude pictures of her were leaked
online.[108] Lawrence emphasized that the images were never meant to go
public; she called the leak a "sex crime" and a "sexual violation". She added
that viewers of the images should be ashamed of their part in a sexual
offense.[109] The actress later stated that her pictures were intended for
Hoult, and that unlike other victims of the hack, she did not plan to sue
[Apple](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.").[106] As of 2014, Lawrence lives in
[Beverly Hills, California](/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California "Beverly Hills,
California").[110] From September 2016 to October 2017, she was in a
relationship with _mother!_ 's director, [Darren
Aronofsky](/wiki/Darren_Aronofsky "Darren Aronofsky").[111][112][113]

[![Jennifer Lawrence waving to the
camera](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Jennifer_Lawrence_Cannes_2013.jpg/170px-
Jennifer_Lawrence_Cannes_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_Cannes_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_Cannes_2013.jpg "Enlarge")

Lawrence at the [2013 Cannes Film Festival](/wiki/2013_Cannes_Film_Festival
"2013 Cannes Film Festival")

Lawrence is a supporter of [Planned Parenthood](/wiki/Planned_Parenthood
"Planned Parenthood"),[114] and she participated in a June 2017 video against
the defunding of the organization.[115] She spoke out against the November
2015 shooting at a Colorado Springs Planned Parenthood clinic.[114] She is a
[feminist](/wiki/Feminism "Feminism"), a concept she argues should not
intimidate people "because it just means equality".[116] Lawrence promotes
[body positivity](/wiki/Body_Positive_Movement "Body Positive Movement") among
women.[117] In 2015, she wrote an essay for the _[Lenny
Letter](/wiki/Lenny_Letter "Lenny Letter")_ in which she criticized the
[gender pay gap](/wiki/Gender_pay_gap "Gender pay gap") in Hollywood. She
wrote about her own experiences in the industry, such as the lesser salary she
received for her work in _American Hustle_ compared to her male co-stars.[118]
In a 2015 interview with _[Vogue](/wiki/Vogue_\(magazine\) "Vogue
\(magazine\)")_ , Lawrence criticized Kentucky county clerk [Kim
Davis](/wiki/Kim_Davis "Kim Davis") for her opposition to [same-sex
marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage").[77] Lawrence was
"raised a [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican
Party \(United States\)")", but has subsequently criticized the party's stance
on women's rights.[77] She has strongly opposed [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s presidency, stating in 2015 that
his election would "be the end of the world".[119]

Lawrence became a member of the [Academy of Motion Picture Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/Academy_of_Motion_Picture_Arts_and_Sciences "Academy of Motion
Picture Arts and Sciences") in 2011.[120] She has lent her support to several
charitable organizations, such as the [World Food
Programme](/wiki/World_Food_Programme "World Food Programme"), [Feeding
America](/wiki/Feeding_America "Feeding America"), and the [Thirst
Project](/wiki/Thirst_Project "Thirst Project").[121] Along with [Josh
Hutcherson](/wiki/Josh_Hutcherson "Josh Hutcherson") and [Liam
Hemsworth](/wiki/Liam_Hemsworth "Liam Hemsworth"), her co-stars of _The Hunger
Games_ (2012), Lawrence partnered with the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") to publicize poverty and
hunger.[122] She organized an early screening of _The Hunger Games: Catching
Fire_ (2013) to benefit Saint Mary's Center, a disabilities organization in
Louisville, and raised more than $40,000 for the cause.[123] She partnered
with the charity broadcast network Chideo to raise funds for the [2015 Special
Olympics World Summer Games](/wiki/2015_Special_Olympics_World_Summer_Games
"2015 Special Olympics World Summer Games") by screening her film _Serena_
(2014).[124] She also collaborated with [Omaze](/wiki/Omaze "Omaze") to host a
fundraising contest for the games as part of the premiere of _The Hunger
Games: Mockingjay – Part 1_ (2014).[125]

In 2015, Lawrence teamed with Hutcherson and Hemsworth for _Prank It FWD_ , a
charitable initiative to raise money for the non-profit organization [Do
Something](/wiki/Do_Something "Do Something").[126] That year, she also
launched the Jennifer Lawrence Foundation, which supports charities such as
the [Boys & Girls Clubs of America](/wiki/Boys_%26_Girls_Clubs_of_America
"Boys & Girls Clubs of America") and the [Special
Olympics](/wiki/Special_Olympics "Special Olympics").[127] In 2016, she
donated $2 million to the [Kosair Children's
Hospital](/wiki/Kosair_Children%27s_Hospital "Kosair Children's Hospital") in
Louisville to set up a cardiac intensive care unit named after her
foundation.[128] Lawrence is a board member of
[Represent.Us](/wiki/Represent.Us "Represent.Us"), a nonprofit seeking to pass
anti-corruption laws in the United States.[129] In 2017, Lawrence joined an
[Omaze](/wiki/Omaze "Omaze") fundraising campaign, through which a winner will
be chosen to go wine tasting with her.[130] The following year, she
collaborated with 300 women in Hollywood to set up the [Time's
Up](/wiki/Time%27s_Up_\(movement\) "Time's Up \(movement\)") initiative to
protect women from harassment and discrimination.[131]

## In the media

In 2012, the review website IndieWire described Lawrence's personality as
"down-to-earth, self-deprecating, [and] unaffected".[132] She is frequently
referred to as "America's Sweetheart" in the media.[133] An [IGN](/wiki/IGN
"IGN") writer considers her to be a "sharp", "funny" and "quirky" actress who
likes to "stay grounded" despite considerable success.[121] Lawrence says that
she finds acting "stupid" and does not believe in being "cocky" about her
success.[134] As a role model to young people, she tries to be careful with
her words.[135]

[![A close-up of Jennifer
Lawrence](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Jennifer_Lawrence_in_2016.jpg/170px-
Jennifer_Lawrence_in_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_in_2016.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jennifer_Lawrence_in_2016.jpg "Enlarge")

Lawrence at the premiere of _[A Beautiful Planet](/wiki/A_Beautiful_Planet "A
Beautiful Planet")_ in 2016

In 2012, _Rolling Stone_ called her "the most talented young actress in
America."[3] Her _Hunger Games_ co-star [Donald
Sutherland](/wiki/Donald_Sutherland "Donald Sutherland") has favorably
compared her craft to that of [Laurence Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier
"Laurence Olivier") and considers her an "exquisite and brilliant actor".[136]
David O. Russell (who directed her in _Silver Linings Playbook_ , _American
Hustle_ and _Joy_) has praised her effortless acting that makes her
performances look easy.[137] During her career, Lawrence has played roles in
both high-profile, mainstream productions and low-budget independent films,
and has appeared in a range of film genres.[121] She did not study acting and
has not been involved in professional theater.[9] She instead bases her acting
approach on her observations of people around her.[138]

> I don't invest any of my real emotions. [I don't take any of my characters'
> pain home with me], I don't even take it to [craft
> services](/wiki/Craft_service "Craft service"). I've never been through
> anything that my characters have been through. And I can't go around looking
> for roles that are exactly like my life. So I just use my imagination. If it
> ever came down to the point where, to make a part better, I had to lose a
> little bit of my sanity, I wouldn't do it. I would just do comedies.
>
> — Lawrence, _[The Globe and Mail](/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail "The Globe and
> Mail")_ , June 2010[9]

As her career has developed, Lawrence has become one of the best paid
actresses; _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily
Telegraph")_ reported in 2014 that she was earning $10 million a film.[135] In
2013, _Time_ magazine named her [one of the most 100 influential people in the
world](/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100"),[139] _[Elle](/wiki/Elle_\(magazine\) "Elle
\(magazine\)")_ labeled her the most powerful woman in the entertainment
business,[140] and _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ ranked her as the 50th
most powerful actress.[141] In 2014, _Forbes_ named her the second-highest-
paid actress in the world with earnings of $34 million,[142] and cited her as
the most powerful actress, ranking at number 12 in the magazine's [Celebrity
100](/wiki/Celebrity_100 "Celebrity 100") list; she appeared in the list again
in 2016.[143][144] In 2015, Lawrence was named "Entertainer of the Year" by
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ —a
title she also won in 2012[145][146]—and was recognized as the highest-
grossing action heroine in _[Guinness World
Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records")_ for starring
in the _Hunger Games_ series.[147] In 2015 and 2016, _Forbes_ reported that
she had emerged as the world's highest-paid actress with annual earnings of
$52 million and $46 million, respectively.[148] The magazine ranked her as the
world's third highest-paid actress in 2017, with earnings of $24 million.[149]

Lawrence appeared in [Victoria's Secret](/wiki/Victoria%27s_Secret "Victoria's
Secret")'s listing of the "Sexiest Up-and-Coming Bombshell" in 2011,[150]
_[People](/wiki/People_\(magazine\) "People \(magazine\)")_ 's Most Beautiful
People in 2011 and 2013,[151] _[Maxim](/wiki/Maxim_\(magazine\) "Maxim
\(magazine\)")_ 's Hot 100 from 2011 to 2014,[152] and topped _[FHM](/wiki/FHM
"FHM")_ 's [sexiest women in the world](/wiki/FHM%27s_100_Sexiest_Women_\(UK\)
"FHM's 100 Sexiest Women \(UK\)") list in 2014.[153] From 2013 to 2015, she
was featured in _[Glamour](/wiki/Glamour_\(magazine\) "Glamour \(magazine\)")_
's annual listing of the best dressed women, topping the list in 2014.[154]

## Accolades

Main article: [List of awards and nominations received by Jennifer
Lawrence](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Jennifer_Lawrence
"List of awards and nominations received by Jennifer Lawrence")

Lawrence won an [Academy Award for Best
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Actress") for her performance in _[Silver Linings
Playbook](/wiki/Silver_Linings_Playbook "Silver Linings Playbook")_ (2012).
She has won three [Golden Globe Awards](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe
Award"); [Best Actress – Comedy or
Musical](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture_Comedy_or_Musical
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical") for
_Silver Linings Playbook_ (2012) and _Joy_ (2015), and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture
"Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture") for
_[American Hustle](/wiki/American_Hustle "American Hustle")_ (2013). She also
won a [BAFTA Award](/wiki/BAFTA_Award "BAFTA Award") for [Best Actress in a
Supporting Role](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actress_in_a_Supporting_Role
"BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role") for _American Hustle_
(2013).[58][65][80] Her other accolades include seven [MTV Movie
Awards](/wiki/MTV_Movie_Awards "MTV Movie Awards") (five for _The Hunger
Games_ series, two for _Silver Linings Playbook_),[158] six [People's Choice
Awards](/wiki/People%27s_Choice_Awards "People's Choice Awards") (three for
_The Hunger Games_ , three for the _X-Men_ series),[159][84] a [Satellite
Award](/wiki/Satellite_Award "Satellite Award") for _Silver Linings Playbook_
,[160] and a [Saturn Award](/wiki/Saturn_Award "Saturn Award") for _The Hunger
Games_.[161]
